text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit:
Holly Hill. It is May the 16th. I’m headed to Oscar Pratt’s house.
Tribes, like there has been for a long time. You have in South Carolina-

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: something like 18 or 19 different groups. What’s going on?

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit:
Well, the way I put it, it’s people who are coming in.
They might be already in. And they think there’s money into it.

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: Out of their own pocket?

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: Well, they think they’ll get money from the federal government.

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: Oh.

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: And they think they’ll start the little tribe up and get something going.

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: And if the federal government ever – In the state of South Carolina, If the federal government ever recognizes the Indians in South Carolina and they have their little tribe going, they figure they’ll get a piece.

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: Most of them are retired.

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: Oh they are?

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: And some of them aren’t retired. They’re still working.

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: Well here in – I noticed that the South Carolina-

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: Archeological Institute has a website, and on that website they list two Santee Indian tribes. Which is your tribe? I know you’re not chief any more, but which is your tribe, and which is this other pop-up tribe?

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: Well, got the fellow named William Kuhns. He’s from Roebuck.

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: Where?

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: Roebuck. Down along the west side around Spartanburg and Greenville.

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: Oh, he’s not even from Santee, here.

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: No. But he claims that his tribe runs from Roebuck down to Greeleyville.

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: What do you think of that?

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: I don’t even – I seen him a couple times. I don’t even speak to him.

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: I’d see him when I was still chief and I would go to meetings. Us older tribes don’t even – but then see, that’s ‘cause his feet got some of us messed up. ‘Cause we didn’t come in –

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: as long as they get their 501C-3 status and they get some paperwork done from whatever, but then see, his (inaudible)  has got to treat him like anybody else.

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: Well that’s got to change, doesn’t it? Isn’t that gonna change?

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: It should. Now they – I read the paper the other day, ‘cause – The state has passed a law that can recognize the tribes in  South Carolina now. But you’ve got to meet all this criteria-

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: to (inaudible) he was gonna recognize who he was not.

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: Of course your tribe will meet that criteria, right?

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: Yes.

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: But these others won’t.

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: The others won’t.

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: Well that’s good.

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: That’ll limit their ability to get recognized, right? Who are their members? Like this other so-called Santee.

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: I don’t know.

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: Are they Indians, are they wannabes?

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: I don’t know that either.

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: I don’t never mess with them. They’ll go from house to house and say, “I’ve got a tribe going. It might be a possibility to get some” – you know people are money crazy and they’ll say,-

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: “Well there’s a possibility there’s some money coming out from the federal government, and if you’re on this list and say you’re an Indian.” You’ve got people that do that. I know that when I was in school, we used to send people to school.

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: I had people from all over the place saying they wanted to be an Indian to get into schools. All they had to do was go up there and change the – back then all you had to do is change the – your voting registration, just register as Indian instead of a white person.

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: Change it to Indian.

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: Their voter’s registration?

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: Yes.

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: That would give them some legitimacy.

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: They’d go to school, and when they got out of school, then they’d change it back to-

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: a white person or whatever it is, but mostly a white person. Gotta change it back to white person. And Native Indians got their education free from the government. ‘Cause see back then the federal government wouldn’t – or the state wasn’t giving-

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: a white person much grant because they wasn’t a minority.

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: Minority – that was during the Civil War era. I mean – not Civil War but Civil Rights era.

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: Right. And so see they’d give the Indians-

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: a little grant thing to go to school with and colored people. So they didn’t wanna be black, so they would say Indian and if they’re changing their registration card to Indian, and then when they get older they’ll change it back to white. And they’ve got an education-

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: Now these were to colleges that cost money, but not to public schools.

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: Right. Speaking of schools. I saw – I got – I’d forgotten away a little bit and I got lost, and I came across this Holly Hill Academy that was started in 1970. Is that really a-

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: reaction of the white people trying to start their own school?

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: That’s a private school.

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: That’s a private school. Are all the students white?

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: No. I think they’ve got a few colored people go there. They had to get them when the-

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: federal government wouldn’t give them – the state wouldn’t give them no tax credit, and so they had to-

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: They have a few.

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: Let anybody come in that had the money to come in.

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: Did any Indians ever go there?

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: We had one little girl went there for a year. This little girl from (inaudible), she went there for a year.

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: I don’t know – I mean, it was too high. She couldn’t afford to go.

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: Yeah. It would be high, wouldn’t it?

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: It would be high. And then I think-

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: Okay.

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: I wouldn’t know what the fee was, ‘cause if I understand I think the fee-

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: for a white person going there and then if a black person or Indian or anybody else wanted to go there, then they could up the fee up so much you don’t (inaudible).

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: You would know, and they would move the fee up if they didn’t want you.

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: If they didn’t want you, right.

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: That’s what it amounted to, right?

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: Mm-hmm.

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: So are there any of the children here going to – on to trade school or college or…? As far as you know.

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: I think there’s a few in Tech. Not many kids in here now. All the people that got kids now have moved out.

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: I see. Where do they move to?

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: Orangeburg, Columbia.

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: I see. So White Oak is getting smaller and smaller. But still, if – well do they have an Indian roll?

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: And do the people who move out-

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: They’re still on the roll.

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: They’re still on the roll, and if there’s a reason to have a vote or something like that, then they can come back and vote.

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: Yeah, right.

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: Even though they don’t live here.

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: They don’t live here. We still communicate with them,-

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: even if they go to Florida. We’ve got a lot of families moving to Florida.

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: Is that right?

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: And they communicate. They’re on the roll.

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: So who’s the new leader?

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: He’s kin to me. I guess if you call him a leader. Roosevelt Scott, which is Tio Scott, which used to be my Vice-Chief for years.

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: That’s his brother.

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: I see. Younger or older?

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: Older. I guess. But I have to admire for him taking it over. Somebody had to take it over, and it’s not legal the way he done it, the way he took over.

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: You mean the vote wasn’t square.

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: There was no vote.

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: Oh.

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: When I resigned, I couldn’t get the council to pull with me

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: like they should be doing, and I seen the things going down the drain. So they didn’t wanna pull with me and I’d been in about 20 years, and I said maybe somebody else can come in.

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: So I resigned, and Tio, he took over. Actually that was his position. He was vice-chief, so he could take over for the chief job.

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: He took it over, but he didn’t do it legitimately.

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: He took it over, but he didn’t stay in but about a month.

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: He couldn’t handle it.

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: Now who is this?

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: Tio, my vice chief.

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: Oh, oh, yes. Right.

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: See his brother – he was retired out of the army

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: and retired from down there at MacDougal [MacDougal Correctional Center], the prison in MacDougal. So he had plenty of time on his hands. But see the bylaws said that a person that runs to be chief

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: has got to have knowledge of the organization and all that. I haven’t been in in there. He didn’t have no knowledge.

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: Do you still have next to the church the community center?

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: Yes.

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: I assume Helen Amos? is no longer around.

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: No, she died about a year ago.

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: A year ago? Is there anybody that has replaced her to help run things?

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: Not in here. See, Helen Amos, she was working with – couldn’t keep it in schools and all that, but she was kind of working for the – she was working for this school up in Rock Hill.

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: Up in Rock Hill she was over all the whatever the grants-

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: Oh, is that that training Training JPEG or something like that? We know what-

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: But you see, you go to Ridgeville, she was over the Edistos. And then Helen was over here, and Helen got sick and had to go in the nursing home. And money has been cut and everything else,-

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: so it’s keeping her and another person out of their money. We just used to going to Ridgeville, ‘cause all of us know the ones in Ridgeville anyway. We’ve been running together for years.

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: But we just send – she sends them to school.

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: Does the tribe get any money from that – what was that? The Training Act. The J whatever it is [TJTC-Targeted Jobs Tax Credit Program].

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: No. The tribe don’t get no money.

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: And they was paying Helen a salary, and then they’ll send the kids to school, but all that come out of Rock Hill. And I know people want-

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: But they never –

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: they don’t get any money either from the ANA, that national group that helps support Indian tribes, ANA.

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: They get some money from somewhere.

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: They are getting some money?

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: I don’t think – yes, money’s coming in, but it’s not the money –

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: there’s no – it’s enough to pay to in-house so much and send so many kids to school in different areas.

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: So that community building is just sort of run-down now and there’s no one in it at all?

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: No. It’s not run-down. We just moved out of it about a year ago. And the new chief, when he took over-

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: Scott.

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: Scott. He took over.

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: It’s been – he thinks that he can run things this big. You don’t – he don’t even – his vice chief-

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: What’s his vice chief’s name?

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: His vice chief is a Crummie.

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: Oh, Hudson’s – one of Hudson’s children?

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: Grandboy.

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: I see.

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: But he’s a good boy. They’re moving the office into a house, and he didn’t know they were moving,-

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: because he works every day. And he comes home. They was moving. He asked them what they’re doing. He (inaudible) the church, ‘cause he always sat out at the church building, anyway.

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: It’s a community for the church, but being on the church ground, we always think of it as the church building, so we always paid rent to the church.

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: I see.

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: But that was paid with the grant.

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: Because it was on the grounds of the church.

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: Right.

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: And it used to be the old school, right?

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: Old school, mm-hmm. But when – you gotta have a grant. It was money put in in that grant to pay rent. So I hear it wasn’t paying no rent, and so the church –

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: not the church – they had a little community board, because we couldn’t pay money to the church, so you had to pay it to a community board. But the community board was over the center,-

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: and that’s who could get the money out of the grant for the center, to keep the center up. So some of the community board members, they didn’t pay the rent.

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: They had to leave. That was because there’s money in the grant for it, and so they hadn’t paid the rent or something, and I (inaudible). Now we don’t have no grant.

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: The last two years we didn’t have no grant. So the tower – you know the old tower up there?

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: Yeah.

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: Well we got Senator Matthews, back when I was in it, and Senator Matthews and-

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: the ones that wrote the grant up (inaudible), ten acres of land and an old house. And it’s come through-

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: a few years ago, when it finally come through about six months ago.

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: So that’ll be…

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: So then that’s the tribal-

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: That’ll be the tribal headquarters.

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: Well that’s good.

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: In the process of fixing it up now. It had a tower on it.

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: Oh, the tower’s not there anymore?

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: Well, they took it down. We had-

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: I noticed the road name is changed. It used to be-

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: Fire Tower Road, but now I didn’t see that sign.

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: No, it’s Bayview Street.

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: Why? Why’d they change it to Bayview? There’s no bay around here.

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: Well we didn’t change it. Whenever they put out this 9-1-1 number,-

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: it’s actually something nobody got behind. They sent out a flyer, I remember, and said if you had any road that you stayed on that you wanted a specific name for-

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: send in and they would name it. Well see nobody didn’t send nothing in and so they didn’t care what you named the road. So see, this road’s coming from here. My dirt road is Church of God Road, because it was a church, and that’s the name of the church.

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: But that’s Bayview Street running through there. The only Indian name that was put on here is a dirt road up on the other end out there, on the other side of the fire tower. There’s a road running through there called Indian Lane.

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: Indian Lane.

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: Right. And that’s the only Indian name through here. The rest of them are-

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: and all kind of different names. They just named anything what they wanted to name it, because nobody was specific. What happened is we should’ve got the community together and named all the roads in this community.

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: Absolutely. Like they did in Ridgeville at Four Holes.

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: Yeah. We should’ve done that, but we didn’t do it.

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: Well that’s the fault of the leadership, isn’t it?

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: Yeah, right.

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: Would you know how many people are in the tribe now?

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: I guess – I don’t exactly know how many’s in there, but it’s still up in the 3 or 4 hundreds.

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: Is that right? Counting everybody that’s moved away?

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: Yeah, moved away.

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: Because they’re still on the tribal roll, and they got a tribal card, and they got all their paperwork in.

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: They moved away primarily for economic reasons, right? Because there’s not –

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: there’s no future around here, economically. You had to travel a long way to where you had one job, and then you had a farm. How’s that? Are you still doing both those two things?

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: I worked yesterday.

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: No kidding.

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: I worked in Mount (inaudible) yesterday, eight hours.

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: Eight hours yesterday. At that same place where you fabricate motor homes?

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: No. That place closed now, and now I’m putting up steel buildings, which is the same thing.

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: I’ve been doing that since ’65.

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: I’ve been doing that since 1965, before I got married.

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: Do you still have a farm?

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: Still have a farm, yeah.

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: Well that’s good.

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: And I don’t know where the land (inaudible) -

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: It had to be ten years, eleven years. See now I own, 90-some acres in there.

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: How many acres? 90?

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: How many acres in total do you have now?

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: I own about 115, 116 acres.

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: Great. What’s your favorite crop? What do you raise the most?

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: Soy beans. And corn. I raise corn. You might see that grass, but that’s corn right there. But see, I don’t know if you – when my daddy would come home, he would say, “Boy you that’s corn’s ate up, the grass has took it ” but see, they got new technology now.

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: You plant corn, and you’ve got the Round-Up. We usually take it for granted. It’s spray-on stuff that kills grass. Well see now they got corn. One thing is Round-Up will kill anything it hits.

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: But see now I can go and take Round-Up and squirt it on that corn there, and-

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: It’ll come up.

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: And it won’t bother it. Technology – when they’ve got the corn. It won’t hurt the corn. But now you take it and spray it on that bush, that bush is dead.

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: Now they got that non-Round-Up corn, the old corn. If you spray on it, it’ll kill it. But they’ve got new corn.

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: That new corn is – can stand it.

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: Yeah. They’ve got genes bred into it that stand Round-Up.

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: Right. Well how do you farm? Do you farm all by yourself? Do you have any of your children helping you?

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: No, I’m by myself.

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: So you have to have machines to do it?

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: Do you still have your-

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: Tractor and the combine. Well see, there’s no – it’s not – corn is easy now.

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: Oh? Because of mechanization.

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: Right. I used to – at corn I would have to-

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: You can buy some stuff to spray on it to get the weed grass out of it, but I don’t want to spray it that bad. I let the corn get that high, and I’d go spray it one time, and it’ll last the whole year. I spray-

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: right on top of it and – see I (inaudible) corn. I plant it and cut it, and that’s it.

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: Huh.

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: So you can spray it faster than you can plow. I can spray it in 30 minutes, and I’m through.

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: So how long’s it take you to cut it-

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: when it’s ripe.

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: Not long. You’ve got four helpers (inaudible) combine. I’m talking running now. You don’t have something breaking down. But you can cut that corn in half an hour.

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: Can I interrupt? I’d like to get a picture of you over by your house. I want it with the clouds are over so it’s not so hard. Is that okay?

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: That’d be fine.

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: 12 heads? Is that what you said?

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: Yeah, 12 heads. My momma had 12 heads. Three of us down in this part of the country. The rest of them are in Columbia and Orangeburg, Charleston, Moncks Corner.

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: Right. Moncks Corner?

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: Yeah, I got a brother staying in Moncks Corner.

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: What’s your brother’s name? Pratt?

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: Sidney.

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: Now down there at Varnerttwn I had heard that they – there’s been Indians down there for a long time.

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: But now they decided to form a tribe. Is that right?

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: Right.

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: Now they’re not like these other pop-up tribes, because they’ve been there for-

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: They’ve been there for years.

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: And…

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: what do you – does he associate with them at all? I know he would belong to this tribe, but does he get together with them at all, do you think?

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: I don’t know if he do or not. He might have, but they’ve got their own – some of their members used to be members of this tribe.

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: Oh. You mean in Varnertown?

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: In Varnertown.

text.speaker: GC
text.text_bit: What would their last names be?

text.speaker: OP
text.text_bit: Scott. I know that. And then some are – my dad used to preach down there.

text.speaker: GC
